Award.AwardTitle: Potential Theory of Functions of Bounded Variation and Quasiconformal Maps
Award.AbstractNarration:
When we view images of objects, what we see are various locations of the object emitting different intensities of light. We can think of the image of the object as formed by a collection of surfaces of different shapes, each with its own uniform brightness. Similarly, in the study of various mathematical objects such as functions that measure temperature at different locations, functions that measure electro-magnetic intensities, and functions that measure the velocity of fluid particles at various places in a fluid, can be understood in terms of the shape of the level sets of the function. (A level set is a set where the function takes on a given constant value.) This project in metric space analysis explores the behavior of functions that arise in the study of potential theory and quasiconformal mappings in terms of level sets. Applications of the the research project include image processing and edge detection. Many components of this project are suitable dissertation material for graduate students, and therefore will contribute to the training of future members of the STEM workforce.

This project is concerned with links between geometry of a metric space given in terms of its sets of finite perimeter on the one hand, and nonlinear potential theory and quasiconformal mappings on the other hand. The spaces considered are equipped with a doubling measure supporting a 1-Poincare inequality. In the first part of the project the PI will explore interactions between collections of sets of finite perimeter and quasiconformal mappings, and between collections of sets of finite perimeter and nonlinear potential theory. The second part of the project will explore "tangent space" regularity of sets of quasiminimal boundary surfaces. The third part of the project is to develop a potential theory for functions of bounded variation. The last part of the project is to obtain a characterization of certain Poincare inequalities in terms of modulus of families of sets of finite perimeter. Applications of the research include further understanding of connections between metric geometry related to sets of finite perimeter and solutions to certain nonlinear partial differential equations. Such sets arise in the study of image processing and edge detection, while abstract metric spaces arise in Riemannian manifolds theory when considering Gromov-Hausdorff limit spaces as found in the works of Cheeger, Gromov, and Perelman. Furthermore, these projects will expand the current knowledge about geometry and the theory of sets of finite perimeter in Carnot-Caratheodory spaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mathematical theory of functions of bounded variation was invented to study smoothness porperties of minimal surfaces; since then this theory has been used to study (i) image processing, (ii) understanding physical phenomena such as blistering of heated surfaces, (iii) partial differential equations describing physical processes on regions with non-smooth boundaries. The research supported by this grant extended the exploration to non-smooth setting that models nature more accurately. It was found that (a) families of sets of finite perimeter are almost preserved by quasiconformal mappings (these mappings arise as higher-dimensional variants of planar conformal transformations and are related to the study of tensile distortion of solids), (b) tangential limits of sets of finite perimeter are quasiminimal surfaces and asymptotic limits of functions of bounded variation at almost every point is a function of least gradient (minimal energy), and that (c) there are three types of Dirichlet problems associated with least gradient functions. As sets of finite perimeter and functions of bounded variation can be quite far from being smooth, it was imperative to find out how badly they behave. This study was also carried out in the project, and we found that such functions are finely continuous outside of their jump sets (cracks in their graphs). The above outcomes were applied to explore Neumann type boundary value problems (problems where the outer normal derivative of the solution, at the boundary of the region of interest, is controlled) in the non-smooth setting such as regions made up of non-smooth materials and certain fractals.

Outcomes from this research were made available in the (freely accessible) arXiv preprint server and were published or submitted for publication in reputed mathematical research journals; 16 research papers cover the outcomes from this project.

The broader impact of this project included training of future STEM workforce, and dissemination of knowledge gained from the project. Much of the research was done in collaboration with researchers from the United States, Sweden, Finland, Spain, and Poland. Rebekah Jones, a PhD student at the PI's home institution, completed her dissertation research as part of this project, and is currently writing here thesis for submission to her dissertation committee. She is expected to graduate in Spring 2019. Three previous PhD students of the PI (Marcos Lopez, Dewey Estep, Xining Li) also contributed to the early part of the project, and they attended conferences to give presentations of their research and to network with other early career mathematicians. The PI also worked with two postdoctoral researchers (Lukas Maly and Panu Lahti) at her home institution on parts of this project, thus contributing to their career development training. The outcomes from this project will form a part of a research monograph the PI will write with colleagues in Italy. The PI also gave presentations on the research outcomes at  professional mathematical conferences and seminars, both in the United States and abroad, in order to disseminate knowledge obtained from the project and form wider collaborative networks. The PI  gave four week-long intensive courses on functions of bounded variation in non-smooth setting to graduate students from the US and Europe; these courses were given in Sweden, Spain, and Italy; the goal here was to help train students to work in the field and to prepare them for a STEM career. The funding also supported a week-long short course on network theory in connection with non-smooth analysis at the PI's home institution; this short course was given by Pietro Poggi-Corradini and Nathan Albin of Kansas State University.
